articles.headline: Executive Charged in TARP Scheme
articles.snippet: The government says Lee Bentley Farkas tried to steal $553 million in federal bailout assistance.
articles.abstract: The government says Lee Bentley Farkas tried to steal $553 million in federal bailout assistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday accused the former chairman of Taylor, Bean & Whitaker, once one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, of masterminding a fraud scheme that cheated investors and the federal government out of billions of dollars and led to last year’s sudden failure of Colonial Bank.

articles.headline: Dividends Like BP’s Look Safe, Until They’re Not
articles.snippet: For investors, the moral of the BP story is clear: diversify — not only into other stocks, but also into other sources of income, like annuities, interest and even asset sales.
articles.abstract: For investors, the moral of the BP story is clear: diversify — not only into other stocks, but also into other sources of income, like annuities, interest and even asset sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you own BP shares and rely on the dividends for your retirement income, you now matter less than shrimp boat owners and tourism workers in the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.headline: A Bold Phone Fades a Bit in the Details
articles.snippet: The new HTC Evo 4G phone from Sprint looks good, runs Flash videos on the Web and lets you type by speaking. What’s the problem?
articles.abstract: The new HTC Evo 4G phone from Sprint looks good, runs Flash videos on the Web and lets you type by speaking. What’s the problem?
articles.lead_paragraph: Fine print, baby. It’s all about the fine print.

articles.headline: Far From Gulf, a Spill Scourge 5 Decades Old
articles.snippet: The Niger Delta region continues to endure spills due to poor regulation, insufficient maintenance and sabotage.
articles.abstract: The Niger Delta region continues to endure spills due to poor regulation, insufficient maintenance and sabotage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BODO, Nigeria  Big oil spills are no longer news in this vast, tropical land. The Niger Delta, where the wealth underground is out of all proportion with the poverty on the surface, has endured the equivalent of the Exxon Valdez spill every year for 50 years by some estimates. The oil pours out nearly every week, and some swamps are long since lifeless.

articles.headline: Push to Market Pill Stirs Debate on Sexual Desire
articles.snippet: A vast marketing campaign has set off debate over what constitutes a normal range of sexual desire for women.
articles.abstract: A vast marketing campaign has set off debate over what constitutes a normal range of sexual desire for women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Viagra met blockbuster success in 1998, the drug industry has sought a similar pill for women.

articles.headline: Housing Market Slows as Buyers Get Picky
articles.snippet: Buyers are walking away when sellers refuse last-minute demands, making a drop in sales worse than expected.
articles.abstract: Buyers are walking away when sellers refuse last-minute demands, making a drop in sales worse than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the recession, people simply looked for a house to buy. Later they got squeamish just thinking about buying. Now they are on a quest for perfection at the perfect price.

articles.headline: In China, Labor Movement Enabled by Technology
articles.snippet: Workers on strike told their stories and tapped into a communications web allowing the working class in China to share grievances and strategies.
articles.abstract: Workers on strike told their stories and tapped into a communications web allowing the working class in China to share grievances and strategies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHONGSHAN, China  It is labor revolt by text message and video upload, underwritten by the Chinese government.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: BP’s Shareholders Take It on the Chin
articles.snippet: Americans own half of the stock in the British oil company, which has lost $88 billion on paper since the oil spill began last month.
articles.abstract: Americans own half of the stock in the British oil company, which has lost $88 billion on paper since the oil spill began last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just how big is this oil spill, really? For BP shareholders, about $88 billion big — and growing.

articles.headline: New Autoworkers Leader Hopes to Revitalize Union
articles.snippet: Bob King was elected U.A.W. president, and will negotiate with carmakers on a union contract next year, when the Big Three are expected to be profitable.
articles.abstract: Bob King was elected U.A.W. president, and will negotiate with carmakers on a union contract next year, when the Big Three are expected to be profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  As a young law student and electrician apprentice at the Ford Motor Company’s mammoth Rouge factory complex, Bob King won support from co-workers who agreed with his radical viewpoints.

articles.headline: Security Tops the Environment in China’s Energy Plan
articles.snippet: Global warming remains a secondary concern as China drafts a comprehensive energy law.
articles.abstract: Global warming remains a secondary concern as China drafts a comprehensive energy law.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  When President Obama called this week for a “national mission” to expand the use of clean energy and increase American energy independence, Chinese officials might have nodded knowingly.

articles.headline: Bullish Signals From G.M. and Toyota
articles.snippet: G.M. plans to skip a summer shutdown at nine factories to increase production, while Toyota aims to make Corollas at a new Mississippi plant in fall 2011.
articles.abstract: G.M. plans to skip a summer shutdown at nine factories to increase production, while Toyota aims to make Corollas at a new Mississippi plant in fall 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Two of the world’s largest automakers signaled confidence in the economic recovery on Thursday, with Toyota announcing it would resume construction of a long-delayed plant in Mississippi and General Motors increasing output at most of its American operations.
